assets.title: Run application using osascript in AppleScript
assets.raw: osascript -e 'tell application "アプリケーション名" to run'

annotations.text: This code snippet uses the osascript command to run an AppleScript that tells a specific application to run. The application name is specified in the script.

This command launches an OS-based application using the osascript tool. It then runs a program to run it with no arguments for example, and allows them to be used as input or output of any other commands in your system.

assets.title: Resetting the public schema in PostgreSQL.

DROP SCHEMA public CASCADE;
CREATE SCHEMA public;

I don't want to drop the database itself, just all tables and all the data in them.
Creates a new schema with the same name as "CASCADE" and creates an existing table.
This code snippet drops the public schema and all its objects, then creates a new public schema.

assets.title: Docker container setup with two hosts on sample network
assets.raw:
version: "2"

services:
  host1:
    image: ubuntu:14.04
    container_name: host1
    command: /bin/sh -c "tail -f /dev/null"
    hostname: host1
    networks:
      sample-network: 
        ipv4_address: 192.168.100.221
  host2:
    image: ubuntu:14.04
    container_name: host2
    command: /bin/sh -c "tail -f /dev/null"
    hostname: host2
    networks:
      sample-network: 
        ipv4_address: 192.168.100.222

networks:
    sample-network:
      external: true

annotations.text: This is a version of 2 that sets up two services, host1 and container_name to "host2", then assigns the IP addresses for each service. It also creates an external network with IPv4 address 192.168.100.221 or

This code snippet defines two containers, host1 and host2, both using the Ubuntu 14.04 image. They are assigned specific IP addresses within the sample-network. The containers are set to run a command that keeps them running indefinitely. The sample

assets.title: Create group mygroup with group ID 1010

How to Create Groups in Linux (groupadd Command)

In this article, we will talk about how to create new groups in Linux, using the groupadd command. Groups are used to organize and administer user accounts.

assets.title: User's groups in Ubuntu
assets.raw:
ubuntu@example:/$ groups testuser
testuser : testgroup testgroup2

annotations.text: This command creates a testuser and group with two groups, one for the user to be used in Ubuntu.
The code snippet displays the groups that the user "testuser" belongs to, which are "testgroup" and "testgroup2".

assets.title: Modify user's group membership using sudo
assets.raw: sudo usermod -G グループ名 ユーザ名

annotations.text: This command sets up a user's security group, allowing users to access their permissions. It also allows the user to change and modify its contents if they are not already in use or remove it from your system.

assets.title: Docker System Prune
assets.raw:
docker system prune
docker system prune -a --volumes

annotations.text: The code snippet is used to clean up unused Docker resources. The first command removes all unused containers, networks, and images. The second command additionally removes all unused volumes and all images not referenced by any container.
This command prunees all Docker systems in the specified volumes and removes any existing containers from a container.

assets.title: Docker Compose Stop and Cleanup Commands
assets.raw:
docker-compose stop
docker-compose down --rmi all --volumes --remove-orphans
docker builder prune
docker compose up

annotations.text: This code snippet stops and removes all containers, images, and volumes created by a Docker Compose project, and then prunes unused Docker builder resources. Finally, it brings up the Docker Compose project again.
Stops and removes orphan volumes from the container, then prunes any existing containers. It also stops Docker builds with a single volume or an empty list oforphans for all

assets.title: Docker Compose Stop, Down, Build, and Up
assets.raw:
docker-compose stop
docker-compose down --rmi all --volumes --remove-orphans
docker-compose build --no-cache
docker compose up

annotations.text: This code snippet stops and removes all containers, images, and volumes created by Docker Compose, then rebuilds and starts the containers.
This command stops and builds a Docker compose with no cache, removes orphan volumes from the root directory.

assets.title: Docker Compose Build with Plain Progress

annotations.text: This command builds a Docker Compose container with the progress of "plain" and displays it in an empty list.
This command builds Docker images using the docker-compose.yml file and displays the build progress in a plain format without any additional information or formatting.

assets.title: Copy process information to clipboard

annotations.text:
How to copy and paste within a terminal in macOS or Linux?

Sometimes we want to store some piece of information while using a terminal. There’s a nice command on Mac & Linux that make it easy for you - check it out!
This code snippet pipes the output of the "ps aux" command into the "pbcopy" command, which copies the output to the clipboard.
This command copies the aux and pbcopy files into a new file called "aux" using Psh.
